title: Richard Osman reveals he confused US woman after using British phrases
text:
Television presenter Richard Osman has sparked an amusing Twitter thread after revealing he left an American woman baffled after using popular British phrases - and admitted even he couldn't offer an explanation.

The Pointless host, 48, took to Twitter and penned: 'Just explained to a delighted American that we call ‘crosswalks’ ‘zebra crossings’.'

'Then she asked what we call ‘crossing guards’, and I said ‘lollipop ladies’ and now she thinks I’ve just made the whole thing up.'

And it wasn't long before people from across the globe took to the comments section to discuss terms they've used that have similarly resulted in confusion.

'Tell her about ROUNDABOUTS,' enthused one, while another added: 'And that our cars have bonnets and boots!'

Richard Osman (pictured in 2014) took to Twitter to explain a confusing exchange he had with an American - and the thread quickly went viral

The TV host told how he explained to the US resident that Brits call ‘crosswalks’ ‘zebra crossings’ and ‘crossing guards’ ‘lollipop ladies.’ Pictured, on Lorraine in London on 19 December 2017

Members of the public contributed to the amusing thread - with one joking: 'How do you explain a Pelican crossing?'

A third wrote: How explain you explain a Pelican crossing?' while a fourth commented: 'I caused much mirth by using the words “clothes horse” this week.'

In the post, which has since been liked 60.6k times, residents from the likes of America and South Africa contributed to the amusing exchange - with the stationery item 'rubber' proving a popular choice.

'In South Africa we call erasers rubbers,' wrote one. 'My dad still cracks me up telling me about the time he did some teaching in Salt Lake City and told his school students he wanted to see a pen, pencil and a rubber on each of their desks the next day.'

A second joked: 'We call them rubbers in the UK too. I’ve still got my childhood rubber collection — that’s not a sentence that goes down well in America.'

Another joked how they'd cause confusion by using the term 'clothes horse' earlier in the week (pictured)

And it seems the US word 'suspenders,' gave Brits the wrong impression for many years too - since it means something rather different here.

'In a very amusing conversation an older lady told me in great detail about finding the right suspenders for her grandson for his wedding,' penned one.

'I finally realised that braces were called suspenders in the US. The conversation made much more sense after this revelation.'

Another joked: 'I grew up thinking that American men were quite kinky because of the suspenders thing!'

Meanwhile, other popular items to initiate confusion include traffic cones and road signs.

'Painted give way triangles are called shark's teeth in The Netherlands,' wrote one, while a second added: 'They're called that on the Faroe Islands too.'

A further penned: 'In Australia we call traffic cones “witches hats” and I’ve only just realised how insane that is,' while a fourth commented:

'And Americans park on a driveway, and drive on a parkway. Madness.'
description: Richard Osman, 48, took to Twitter to explain how he confused an American woman after using the British phrases 'zebra crossings' and 'lollipop ladies' - and joked even he didn't have an explanation.
